name: Saint Matthew
shortDescription: Tax collector called by Jesus to become apostle and evangelist, author of the Gospel emphasizing Jesus as Jewish Messiah and fulfillment of prophecy
longDescription: Matthew (also called Levi, son of Alphaeus) stands as the remarkable bridge between Judaism and Christianity. A tax collector in Capernaum under Herod Antipas, he was despised by his fellow Jews for collaborating with Roman occupation. Yet Jesus saw beyond social stigma, calling Matthew from his tax booth with the simple command 'Follow me.' Matthew immediately left everything - his lucrative position, his security, his identity as outsider - to become one of the Twelve Apostles. His Gospel, written primarily for Jewish-Christian audiences, presents Jesus as the long-awaited Messiah who fulfills every prophecy, from virgin birth in Bethlehem to the Suffering Servant. The five great discourses of Matthew's Gospel (Sermon on the Mount, Missionary Discourse, Parables, Church Discourse, and Olivet Discourse) deliberately mirror the five books of Moses, presenting Jesus as the new Moses giving new law from a new mountain. Matthew's fulfillment formula - 'This was to fulfill what was spoken by the prophet' - appears over a dozen times, systematically connecting Jesus' life to Isaiah, Micah, Zechariah, Hosea, and Jeremiah. His unique use of 'Kingdom of Heaven' rather than 'Kingdom of God' reflects Jewish reverence for the divine name. According to tradition, after Pentecost Matthew preached in Judea before traveling to Ethiopia, Persia, Syria, and Macedonia, suffering martyrdom by sword or spear. His transformation from despised tax collector to beloved evangelist embodies the Gospel's message: divine grace transcends human categories, calling the unworthy to extraordinary purpose.

primaryLocation.name: Capernaum
primaryLocation.description: Fishing village and toll station on the Via Maris where Matthew collected taxes
primaryLocation.significance: Location of Matthew's calling from the tax booth

associatedLocations.name: Galilee
associatedLocations.significance: Region of Jesus' primary ministry where Matthew followed him

associatedLocations.name: Jerusalem
associatedLocations.significance: Site of Pentecost and early apostolic ministry

associatedLocations.name: Ethiopia
associatedLocations.significance: Traditional mission field and site of martyrdom according to some traditions

associatedLocations.name: Persia
associatedLocations.significance: Alternative tradition for later ministry and martyrdom

temporal.culturalPeriod: Second Temple Judaism / Apostolic Era (1st century CE)

literaryReferences.author: Matthew (traditionally attributed)
literaryReferences.significance: First Gospel in canonical order, emphasizing Jewish fulfillment

literaryReferences.author: Mark
literaryReferences.significance: Parallel account of Matthew's calling (as Levi) in Mark 2:14

literaryReferences.author: Luke
literaryReferences.significance: Parallel account of Matthew's calling (as Levi) in Luke 5:27-32

literaryReferences.author: Eusebius of Caesarea
literaryReferences.significance: Earliest church tradition about Matthew writing in Hebrew

biography.earlyLife: Son of Alphaeus, became a tax collector (telones) at Capernaum, collecting customs duties on goods passing through on the Via Maris trade route. Tax collectors were despised by fellow Jews as collaborators with Rome and assumed to be dishonest.
biography.education: Literate in Aramaic, Greek, and likely Hebrew; trained in Roman accounting methods; knowledge of Jewish Scriptures evident in Gospel
biography.calling: While sitting at the tax booth (telonion) in Capernaum, Jesus passed by and said simply, 'Follow me.' Matthew immediately rose and followed, leaving behind his lucrative but despised profession.

majorEvents.event: The Call from the Tax Booth
majorEvents.description: Jesus saw Matthew at the tax collector's station and called him to discipleship with the words 'Follow me' (Matthew 9:9)
majorEvents.significance: Demonstrates Jesus' radical acceptance of social outcasts

majorEvents.description: Matthew hosted a great banquet in Jesus' honor, inviting fellow tax collectors and sinners (Matthew 9:10-13)
majorEvents.significance: Jesus' response 'I desire mercy, not sacrifice' quotes Hosea 6:6

majorEvents.description: Chosen as one of the Twelve Apostles (Matthew 10:3)
majorEvents.significance: A tax collector elevated to inner circle of disciples

majorEvents.description: Present for major events: Sermon on Mount, miracles, Transfiguration, Last Supper, Crucifixion, Resurrection appearances
Received Holy Spirit with other disciples in the Upper Room (Acts 1:13-14, 2:1-4)
Wrote Gospel (or collection of sayings) emphasizing Jesus as Jewish Messiah
majorEvents.significance: Created systematic presentation of fulfillment theology

majorEvents.description: Preached first in Judea, then traveled to Ethiopia, Persia, Macedonia according to various traditions
Killed by sword (some traditions say spear or axe) while celebrating Mass, possibly in Ethiopia or Persia
majorEvents.significance: Gave life for faith he proclaimed

achievements: Authored Gospel of Matthew, first in New Testament canon
Developed fulfillment theology connecting Jesus to Hebrew prophecy
Preserved Sermon on the Mount teachings
Recorded unique parables (Ten Virgins, Talents, Sheep and Goats)
biography.legacy: Patron saint of accountants, bankers, tax collectors, and customs officers. His Gospel became the most quoted in early church. Feast day September 21 (Western) / November 16 (Eastern). Symbol: winged man/angel (from Ezekiel's four living creatures). Relics claimed by Salerno Cathedral, Italy since 954 CE.

fulfillmentFormula.description: Matthew's distinctive phrase introducing Old Testament prophecies fulfilled in Jesus
fulfillmentFormula.formula: This was to fulfill what was spoken by the prophet...

fiveDiscourses.description: Matthew organizes Jesus' teaching into five major blocks, each ending with 'When Jesus had finished...' - mirroring the five books of Torah

kingdomOfHeaven.description: Matthew's preferred term (32 times) versus 'Kingdom of God' (4 times)
kingdomOfHeaven.significance: Reflects Jewish reverence for God's name (circumlocution)

parallels: Birth threatened by king who kills infants (Pharaoh/Herod)
Gave law from mountain (Sinai/Sermon on Mount)

uniqueContent.description: Material found only in Matthew's Gospel
items: Parable of Pearl of Great Price

deities.name: Jesus Christ
deities.relationship: Master and Lord; subject of Matthew's Gospel

deities.name: God the Father
deities.relationship: Revealed through Son in Matthew's theology

heroes.name: Peter
heroes.relationship: Fellow apostle, prominent in Matthew's Gospel

heroes.name: James son of Zebedee
heroes.relationship: Fellow apostle and member of Twelve

heroes.name: Moses
heroes.relationship: Typological parallel; Jesus as new Moses in Matthew

places.name: Capernaum
places.relationship: Location of calling from tax booth

places.name: Jerusalem
places.relationship: Site of Pentecost and early ministry

corpusQueries.description: Matthew's banquet where Jesus ate with tax collectors and sinners

corpusQueries.label: Mercy, Not Sacrifice

query.term: I will have mercy and not sacrifice

corpusQueries.description: Jesus quoting Hosea 6:6 in response to Pharisees' criticism

corpusQueries.label: Fulfillment Quotations

query.term: that it might be fulfilled which was spoken

corpusQueries.description: Matthew's distinctive formula introducing Old Testament prophecies

query.term: Blessed are the poor in spirit for theirs is the kingdom of heaven

corpusQueries.label: Kingdom of Heaven
corpusQueries.description: Matthew's distinctive terminology for God's reign

corpusQueries.label: Genealogy of Jesus Christ

query.term: book of the generation of Jesus Christ the son of David the son of Abraham

corpusQueries.description: Matthew's opening tracing Jesus' lineage to Abraham and David

query.term: Behold a virgin shall be with child and shall bring forth a son
thou Bethlehem in the land of Juda art not the least among the princes

corpusQueries.label: Called Out of Egypt

query.term: Out of Egypt have I called my son

corpusQueries.description: Hosea 11:1 fulfilled in return from Egypt

corpusQueries.label: The Great Commission

query.term: Go ye therefore and teach all nations baptizing them

corpusQueries.description: Final command unique to Matthew's Gospel

corpusQueries.label: The Lord's Prayer

query.term: Our Father which art in heaven Hallowed be thy name

corpusQueries.description: The model prayer taught in Sermon on the Mount

corpusQueries.label: Matthew in the Twelve
corpusQueries.description: Matthew identified as tax collector among the Twelve

corpusQueries.label: Triumphal Entry Fulfillment

query.term: thy King cometh unto thee meek and sitting upon an ass

corpusQueries.description: Zechariah 9:9 fulfilled in Palm Sunday entry

corpusQueries.label: Thirty Pieces of Silver

query.term: thirty pieces of silver the price of him

corpusQueries.description: Zechariah fulfillment in Judas' betrayal price

evangelistSymbol.origin: Ezekiel 1:10, Revelation 4:7 - the four living creatures
evangelistSymbol.interpretation: Represents human genealogy opening Matthew's Gospel; Christ's humanity emphasized

artisticDepictions: Called from tax booth by Jesus
Seated with money bag and book

fullDescription: Tax collector called by Jesus to become apostle and evangelist, author of the Gospel emphasizing Jesus as Jewish Messiah fulfilling every prophecy from Hebrew Scripture

metadata.agentPerspective: Jewish-Christian continuity, prophetic fulfillment, Jesus as Messiah
